items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant that his budget will not make inflation worse and force the Reserve Bank's hand on interest rates — but economists are divided.

title.children: What does the federal budget mean for inflation and interest rates?

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit, tie and glasses, stands and smiles. Blurred tree branches in the background.

items.synopsis: A series of measures aimed at tackling the cost-of-living crisis has been delivered as part of this year's federal budget. Follow the live updates.

title.children: PM defends rise in JobSeeker as advocates say federal budget increase isn't enough

schema.headline: Federal budget 2023 live: Cost-of-living relief measures met with mixed response as Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers budget

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Hey ChatGPT, is there any money in the budget for artificial intelligence?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ChatGPT has declined to comment. But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran: Artificial intelligence is getting a boost, with the federal government tipping in $101.2 million over the next five years to help businesses integrate AI and quantum technologies. That includes expanding the National AI Centre and its role in making sure the technology is responsible (I, Robot, anyone?) as well as setting up the Australian Centre for Quantum Growth. Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important: "Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us. "So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools." Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right. "We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says. "This funding enables smaller Australian innovative companies to access government support, to commercialise their IP and their technology, to really bring that to the market and also [retain] really smart people, so [we] don't lose them overseas. "It’s a really good down payment on securing Australia’s future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Modest cost-of-living measures 'will sadly make little difference to many'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's according to Julie Edwards from Jesuit Social Services. She says while the budget includes some positive investments to tackle the cost-of-living, the increase to the Jobseeker payment will do little to lift vulnerable people out of poverty. Julie: We know that many aspects of the cost of living are at near record highs, including rental prices, petrol, groceries and other essentials, which makes it even less sustainable for a Jobseeker recipient to live a dignified life. We saw during the pandemic that increased payments reduced measures of poverty and housing stress, but a very modest increase of $2.80 per day will sadly make little difference to many. Our political leaders must create a fair social safety net that ensures all Jobseeker recipients can afford an adequate standard of living.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Nationals slams Labor for new tax on regional Australians
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Anna Pykett and Wing Kuang Nationals leader David Littleproud has slammed the federal government for introducing a new fresh food tax for farmers to cover biosecurity costs. The federal budget announced a 10 per cent increase in agricultural levies to fund biosecurity activities and organisations, expecting it to raise $153 million over three years. Littleproud told ABC NewsRadio that this is an "outrageous move". "They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding this would not help address food price inflation. He also says regional Australians will have few benefits from Labor's cost-of-living package, stressing what's needed in regional Australia is infrastructure and new childcare places. He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians may face more accessibility issues in the future. "We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget is 'unfair and inflationary', Shadow Treasurer says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has criticised Labor's spending in the budget, and says it doesn't address the root cause of inflation. The budget offers a $14.6 billion cost of living package, including a $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker, which the Liberal Party hasn't yet taken a position on. "Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: that's inflationary," he told RN this morning. "What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody. "That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away." You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Queensland housing needs more, industry figures say
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Jemima Burt Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland. This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects. But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing. "Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs … If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said. She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty. "There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment. "Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PM rejects claims budget could lead to further rate hikes
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The prime minister says his government has "got the balance right" and delivered a "responsible" budget.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Victorian groups welcome ‘modest’ cost of living help
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Tim Callanan Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed “modest” increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis. That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the government’s energy bill relief plan. Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people. “There's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,” she said. However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be “tough”. “We've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,” she said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Climate Council says budget is 'a warm up lap in history's most important race'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Amanda McKenzie, CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary. McKenzie: This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower people’s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables. Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks. The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for WA?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By state political reporter Keane Bourke There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector. Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful. Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit … below the $500 going to those along the east coast. From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for infrastructure projects in NSW?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Questions from you: What happened to the Help to Buy scheme?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market  - Josh. Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year. The federal government committed in that budget to $324.6 million over four years to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government. The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does the opposition continue to support stage 3 tax cuts?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "We went to an election promising it, as did the prime minister. And there's about 17 broken promises now that the prime minister sits on and surely he's not going to add this one to the list as well. "I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment. "But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What about the billions to help encourage more GPs to offer bulk-billing?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll have more to say about that, but clearly more needs to be done in the bulk-billing space and more needs to be done in general practice and in primary care," Dutton says. "So in principle, we support more assistance to doctors to help them see patients, particularly those with acute needs and those that that require regular attendance at GPs and that includes pensioners and kids, as the government has proposed last night."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does Dutton support the single-parent payment?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll have more to say about that Michael tomorrow night and some other measures as well," Dutton replies. When pressed, the opposition leader says: "Of course [single mums deserve all the help they can], and there's million families more. "Single-parent families, families with kids who are $25,000 worse off under this government and there are lots of people that deserve support because Labor has created a huge cost of living crisis and in this budget, they put upward pressure on interest rates at exactly the belong time."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does Dutton support the JobSeeker increase?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll look at all of those figures and make an announcement in relation to that tomorrow night," Dutton replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dutton calls energy-relief payments a 'short-term fix'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We support those payments to families in the way in which the government has proposed them," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "But it's a short-term fix and the problem is it's a long-term problem that they have created. "There are lots of families, millions of families, who aren't getting any assistance in this budget, who thought they were an average family with a mortgage, three children, $25,000 worse, they're worse off under Labor in this budget. That's a huge hit."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Voice debate having a 'difficult impact' on Indigenous Australians
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "There's money there for the referendum, which is right because we have a referendum coming up, but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PM pressed on difference between cost-of-living package and stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there — perhaps more than some people — would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000. If you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'We got the balance right': PM responds to JobSeeker criticism
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Independent senator David Pocock describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?" Michael Rowland asks the prime minister. "There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me," Anthony Albanese says. "You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right. "We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget 'takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation', PM says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is currently speaking to Michael Rowland on News Breakfast. Rowland : "$20 billion in new spending, is that really going to help force the inflation dragon back into its cave?" Albanese : "$40 billion of savings over two budgets, 87 per cent of the revenue gains put to the bottom line unlike our predecessors where the number was 40 per cent or the Howard government where the number was 30 per cent. This is a budget that takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How hard is it for uni students to live off Youth Allowance?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Before this year's budget, the highest rate a single, childless person on Youth Allowance could receive was around $14,600 a year — so how hard is it to live off the welfare payment? The ABC's Shalailah Medhora has more 👇

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers calls budget surplus a 'complex balancing act'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has handed down his second budget, which looks good for the government, but what is in it for you? Have a look at this cheat sheet of what's set to receive more funding — and who will be paying for it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Bandt says extra JobSeeker money 'not enough to buy a loaf of bread'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: $40 per fortnight for JobSeeker 'clearly not enough', ACOSS CEO says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Cassandra Goldie, the chief executive of the Australian Council of Social Service, says the $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker is "clearly not enough". "Every dollar for somebody on a very low income will make a difference but it is not enough," she told ABC News Breakfast. "We still today have a JobSeeker unemployment payment which is a poverty payment. It is one of the lowest in the OECD and we need to get it to where it should be."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could we see another interest rate rise because of the federal budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant his second budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief — but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced. Some economists have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank. You can continue reading this story by business reporter Kate Ainsworth below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BCA chief says government delivered 'solid budget' but opportunities were missed
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Didn't catch the budget last night? Here's what you need to know
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about: There will be $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J obSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients Bulk-billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by 15 per cent

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget. Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Federal budget 2023 live: Cost-of-living relief measures met with mixed response as Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers budget

You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Jemima Burt Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland. This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects. But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing. "Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs … If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said. She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty. "There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment. "Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland housing needs more, industry figures say

children.content: By Jemima Burt
Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland.
This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects.
But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing.

"Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs … If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said.
(ABC Radio Brisbane: Lucy Stone)
She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty.
"There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment.
"Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Tim Callanan Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed “modest” increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis. That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the government’s energy bill relief plan. Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people. “There's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,” she said. However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be “tough”. “We've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,” she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victorian groups welcome ‘modest’ cost of living help

children.content: By Tim Callanan
Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed “modest” increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis.
That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the government’s energy bill relief plan.
Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people.

“There's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,” she said.
However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be “tough”.
“We've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,” she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Amanda McKenzie, CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary. McKenzie: This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower people’s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables. Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks. The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Climate Council says budget is 'a warm up lap in history's most important race'

children.content: Amanda McKenzie,
CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary.
McKenzie:

This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower people’s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables.

Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks.

The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By state political reporter Keane Bourke There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector. Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful. Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit … below the $500 going to those along the east coast. From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for WA?

children.content: By state political reporter Keane Bourke
There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector.
Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful.
Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit … below the $500 going to those along the east coast.
From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for infrastructure projects in NSW?

children.content: (ABC News: Chris Gillette)
Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan.

Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year.

, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning.
There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program.
The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market  - Josh. Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year. The federal government committed in that budget to $324.6 million over four years to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government. The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions from you: What happened to the Help to Buy scheme?

children.content: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market
- Josh
Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter
Jake Evans
who says:
The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year.
The federal government committed in that budget to
$324.6 million over four years
to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government.
The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "We went to an election promising it, as did the prime minister. And there's about 17 broken promises now that the prime minister sits on and surely he's not going to add this one to the list as well. "I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment. "But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the opposition continue to support stage 3 tax cuts?

children.content: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast.

"We went to an election promising it, as did the prime minister. And there's about 17 broken promises now that the prime minister sits on and surely he's not going to add this one to the list as well.
"I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment.
"But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We'll have more to say about that, but clearly more needs to be done in the bulk-billing space and more needs to be done in general practice and in primary care," Dutton says. "So in principle, we support more assistance to doctors to help them see patients, particularly those with acute needs and those that that require regular attendance at GPs and that includes pensioners and kids, as the government has proposed last night."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What about the billions to help encourage more GPs to offer bulk-billing?

"So in principle, we support more assistance to doctors to help them see patients, particularly those with acute needs and those that that require regular attendance at GPs and that includes pensioners and kids, as the government has proposed last night."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We'll have more to say about that Michael tomorrow night and some other measures as well," Dutton replies. When pressed, the opposition leader says: "Of course [single mums deserve all the help they can], and there's million families more. "Single-parent families, families with kids who are $25,000 worse off under this government and there are lots of people that deserve support because Labor has created a huge cost of living crisis and in this budget, they put upward pressure on interest rates at exactly the belong time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does Dutton support the single-parent payment?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We support those payments to families in the way in which the government has proposed them," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "But it's a short-term fix and the problem is it's a long-term problem that they have created. "There are lots of families, millions of families, who aren't getting any assistance in this budget, who thought they were an average family with a mortgage, three children, $25,000 worse, they're worse off under Labor in this budget. That's a huge hit."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "There's money there for the referendum, which is right because we have a referendum coming up, but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there — perhaps more than some people — would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000. If you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Independent senator David Pocock describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?" Michael Rowland asks the prime minister. "There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me," Anthony Albanese says. "You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right. "We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?

"We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant his second budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief — but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced. Some economists have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank. You can continue reading this story by business reporter Kate Ainsworth below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget. Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning!

children.content: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget.
Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has criticised Labor's spending in the budget, and says it doesn't address the root cause of inflation. The budget offers a $14.6 billion cost of living package, including a $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker, which the Liberal Party hasn't yet taken a position on. "Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: that's inflationary," he told RN this morning. "What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody. "That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away." You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget is 'unfair and inflationary', Shadow Treasurer says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'

liveBlogUpdate.headline: AAA credit rating reaffirmed after budget by ratings agency
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As a person, your credit rating is a summary of whether you're a 'good risk'. If you're not - say you've been late with paying your bills or defaulted on a mortgage - you're pay a higher interest rates on loans to take account of the fact you're more risky (for the lender) than other people. For nation's it's similar. Ratings agencies work out if you, a company or a nation are a 'good risk'. New comments from Fitch Ratings in the wake of the 2023 Australian federal budget are broadly supportive "The return to a underlying cash surplus in the current fiscal year and clear improvement in the federal government's fiscal position over the budget's forecast horizon is supportive of Australia's 'AAA' sovereign rating," said Jeremy Zook, director, sovereigns, APAC at Fitch Ratings. "Fiscal outcomes are stronger than what we expected when we last affirmed Australia's rating with a Stable outlook in December 2022." It also says the budget won't boost inflation. "The government's decision to allow higher than expected revenue collection to flow through to improved budget outcomes by keeping spending relatively contained, points to a commitment to its fiscal strategy and is not likely to contribute to inflationary pressures in the economy. We think the budget assumptions are reasonable and commodity price assumptions remain modest compared to our forecasts. Still, downside risks persist given the weak global outlook, elevated inflation and high interest rates Mr Zook does see "structural budget pressures" over the medium-term and warns that risks to the rating could build with spending demands "particularly the NDIS".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What does this mean for the years ahead?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We can get very caught up in the urgency of now as we assess who's 'won' and 'lost' in the federal budget. My colleague Gareth Hutchens has examined the broader themes of the budget, and what it means for the years and decades ahead. Check it out.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US debt ceiling debate weighs on Wall Street
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Wall Street has posted moderate losses, and the negative sentiment is likely to weigh on Australian markets this morning. Investors traded more cautiously ahead of a meeting between US President Joe Biden, Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday (local time), to discuss the debt ceiling stand-off. The Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.2%, 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively. Markets are waiting to hear the outcome of a meeting on Tuesday (local time) between US President Joe Biden, Worries of a potential government default loom over Washington as early as June 1, if Congress does not act to resolve the deadlock. The Democratic president is calling on lawmakers to raise the federal government's self-imposed borrowing limit without conditions. But the Republican House speaker, Mr McCarthy, has said his chamber will not approve any deal that does not cut spending to address a growing budget deficit. Past debt ceiling fights have typically ended with a hastily arranged agreement in the final hours of negotiations, thus avoiding a default. In 2011, the scramble prompted a downgrade of the country's top-notch credit rating. Veterans of that battle warn the current situation is even riskier because political divides have widened. Economists warn a lengthy default could send the US economy into a deep recession with soaring unemployment, while destabilising the global financial system that's built on US bonds.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Full budget wrap in The Business
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Catch up on last night's comprehensive wrap of the federal budget with a special extended edition of The Business. Small business owners, Finance Minister Katy Gallagher and our panel of experts pick apart the highlights and key themes revealed in the budget documents.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget repair?  "Missed opportunity" says former Treasury official
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A small and extremely rare surplus (spending less money than we make) has been banked by the federal government in its budget. But a former Treasury official says the Treasurer has avoided what was an opportunity to pay down our debt — set to top $1 trillion — as we pay more on interest payments for it. Hear more about it from my colleague Peter Ryan here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Inflation still hot: Will the budget help or hinder?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The increase in the cost of living from the 'inflation' in the price of key things — food, fuel and housing — has made life tougher for people. That's because wages and welfare payments aren't rising as fast, mean a cut to 'real wages' as people's purchasing power falls. With inflation currently at 7% for the year, will the budget make it better or worse? My colleague Stephanie Chalmers has been looking into it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Business benefits in budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers didn't talk a lot about business in his budget speech, instead focussing on household cost-of-living pressures. The elements that will have an impact are around Australia's role in the zero emissions economy of the future: renewable energy and the transition away from fossil fuels.

children.content: Hi team,
I'll be taking you through the morning as the market digests last night's Federal Budget and all of Jim's decisions.
Stay tuned for news and developments through the day.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wall Street has posted moderate losses, and the negative sentiment is likely to weigh on Australian markets this morning. Investors traded more cautiously ahead of a meeting between US President Joe Biden, Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday (local time), to discuss the debt ceiling stand-off. The Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.2%, 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively. Markets are waiting to hear the outcome of a meeting on Tuesday (local time) between US President Joe Biden, Worries of a potential government default loom over Washington as early as June 1, if Congress does not act to resolve the deadlock. The Democratic president is calling on lawmakers to raise the federal government's self-imposed borrowing limit without conditions. But the Republican House speaker, Mr McCarthy, has said his chamber will not approve any deal that does not cut spending to address a growing budget deficit. Past debt ceiling fights have typically ended with a hastily arranged agreement in the final hours of negotiations, thus avoiding a default. In 2011, the scramble prompted a downgrade of the country's top-notch credit rating. Veterans of that battle warn the current situation is even riskier because political divides have widened. Economists warn a lengthy default could send the US economy into a deep recession with soaring unemployment, while destabilising the global financial system that's built on US bonds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US debt ceiling debate weighs on Wall Street
